revised_title: Neural Tube Manipulation and Brain Development in Amphibians
tldr: The authors conducted experiments on amphibian embryos, specifically Xenopus laevis, to study the formation of the brain and nerve connections following embryonic manipulation of the neural tube. They found that the neural tube consists of a mosaic of regions with a fixed tendency to develop into specific parts of the nervous system. The authors also discovered that the axial polarity of the retino-tectal projection is determined within the early neural tube, but the polarity for selective nerve connections remains labile. This research provides insights into the developmental processes of the nervous system and the mechanisms underlying the formation of specific synaptic connections.
